dmca.title: Demand to Cease and Desist from Infringing upon Trademarks and Copyrights of the McCa
dmca.body:
[Private]:

This firm represents The McCall Pattern Company ("McCall").

As you are aware, McCall is the preeminent manufacturer of clothing
patterns.  McCall markets and sells its goods under several famous
registered trademarks, including MCCALL'S?, BUTTERICK?, VOGUE?,
and SEE & SEW? (the "McCall Marks").  Each of its products are delivered
to consumers in distinct packaging displaying original artwork and designs
(the "McCall Designs") protected by registered copyrights.  For decades,
consumers have recognized the McCall Marks and McCall Designs as
identifying McCall as the source of the most exceptional quality patterns on
the market.

McCall offers each pattern to consumers for a limited period of time.  
Consequently, when a consumer sees a MCCALL'S? pattern it expects the
most current and highest caliber pattern available.  However, you are
infringing upon the McCall Marks and McCall Designs, and are purporting to
sell discontinued McCall goods at your Internet storefront,
MonsterPatterns.com (the "Site").  Your acts constitute trademark
infringement, copyright infringement, unfair competition, and other violations
of McCall's rights as described below, and you are liable to our client as a
result.

YOUR WRONGFUL ACTS

McCall sells its patterns to consumers through licensed distributors.  The
distributors agree by a strict contract to sell each pattern only until McCall
discontinues the item, and then destroy all unsold goods.  Indeed, the

distributors must certify the destruction in order to receive a credit from McCall.

You have unlawfully acquired McCall's patterns and are now selling discontinued patterns
on the Site.   Moreover, you are conducting all of your advertising and sales activity by way
of blatant acts of trademark infringement, copyright infringement, and consumer fraud.

FEDERAL AND STATE TRADEMARK INFRINGEMENT

The Lanham Act, at Title 15 United States Code ?? 1114,1125, prohibits the unauthorized
commercial use of a registered mark in connection with the sale, distribution, or advertising
of any goods if such use is likely to cause confusion among consumers as to affiliation,
connection, or approval by the owner of the mark.  The Lanham Act provides for an
injunction against the infringer, as well as substantial damages against a party using a
registered mark without permission, including (1) recovery of the infringer's profits, (2)
recovery of loss to the trademark owner, and (3) an award of attorneys' fees and costs of
suit.  Additionally, the court may increase those damages by three times their actual
amount.  State laws1 provide for similar remedies and damages against trademark
infringers.

In violation of McCall's federal and state trademark rights, you have reproduced the McCall
Marks and placed them prominently on your Site.  Your display of the McCall Marks on the
home page and in several other pages would lead a reasonable consumer to believe that
McCall endorses your Site.  Moreover, you have placed the McCall Marks in metatags
underlying the html code comprising your Site[2].  As a result, potential customers seeking
the McCall site are diverted to your Site.  You are thereby taking sales away from McCall
and its distributors.  Finally, you have purchased and used McCall Marks on the Overture[3]
pay-for-performance search engine and other pay-for-performance search engines, thereby
causing search engine users to believe your site is really McCall's site or the site of one of
its distributors.



       [1]See NY CLS Gen Bus Article 24 (the state trademark law in New York, where McCall is based); Mich.
Comp. Laws ? 429.31, et. seq. (the state trademark law in Michigan, where you reside); Rev. Code
Wash. ? 19.77.010, et. seq. (the state trademark law in Washington, where the Site is hosted and propagated to
the world).

       [2]See, Bihari et al. v. Gross et al., 119 F. Supp. 2d 309 (S.D.N.Y. 2000); Brookfield Communciations, Inc.
v. West Coast Entertainment Corp., 174 F.3d 1036 (9th Cir. 1999).  These cases hold that metatag infringement
such as your acts constitute trademark infringement and entitle the trademark owner to the full damages allowable
under the Lanham Act.

       [3]The search results you purchased under the McCall Marks result in confusion not only on Overture's
site, but via all its licensees including Yahoo, America Online, Microsoft Network, Earthlink, Lycos, AltaVista,
Netscape, Hotbot, Cnet, and Compuserve.

Your unauthorized uses of McCall Marks cause consumer confusion as to the origin,
approval, sponsorship, and affiliation of the products you sell.  Accordingly, you have
committed several acts of trademark infringement.

COPYRIGHT INFRINGEMENT

By displaying the McCall Designs without authorization, you are committing copyright
infringement.  The United States Copyright Act provides at Title 17 United States Code ?
504 for an election of copyright damages (i) that statutorily range from $750.00 US at a
minimum to $150,000.00 US at a maximum for each and every infringement (each
reproduction and display of each of the McCall Designs is in and of itself a separate and
distinct infringement); or (ii) equal to the copyright owner's actual damages and any
additional profits of the infringer.  The Copyright Act also provides for felony criminal
sanctions (at 17 USC ? 506), including up to five (5) years in prison (per infringement) for
the principal of an infringing organization.  

You are hereby on notice that neither you nor MonsterPatterns.com LLC owns nor has a
license to the copyright rights in the McCall Designs.  Accordingly, your reproduction and
display of the McCall Designs on the Site, or elsewhere, constitutes copyright infringement
and qualifies for the maximum penalties under the United States Copyright Act.

UNFAIR COMPETITION AND OTHER VIOLATIONS

By surreptitiously acquiring and then selling discontinued McCall patterns, you are violating
unfair competition laws that prohibit the misappropriation of the skill, expenditures, and
labor of another[4].  This includes not only misappropriating the goodwill of another company
by misleading the public as to sponsorship or endorsement, but also unfairly competing by
generating sales from wrongfully obtained goods.

McCall requires destruction of discontinued patterns for, among other reasons, to reduce
competition between current and past products.  You came into possession of discontinued
McCall goods through improper and unlawful means, and you are now selling the items
and gaining revenue therefrom.  As a result, McCall is faced with discontinued items in the
marketplace, reducing the value of current items and the goodwill associated with McCall
and its products.  While you are making money from this illegal activity, McCall and its
distributors are losing sales, goodwill, consumer recognition, and revenue, for which loss
you are directly responsible.

Similarly, your sale of discontinued McCall patterns constitutes tortious interference
between McCall and its authorized distributors.  Tortious interference is illegal under state


     [4]See, Weight Watchers International, Inc. v. Stouffer Corp., 744 F.Supp. 1259 (S.D.N.Y. 1990)




1178-0002

 

[Private]
February 3, 2003

laws, and occurs when a party has knowledge of a contract but intentionally and improperly
interferes with that contract.  You are well aware that McCall requires its distributors to
destroy discontinued items and certify the same.  Nonetheless, you are stealing or copying
discontinued patterns from McCall's distributors, intentionally interfering with those
agreements and improperly profiting from your acts.

DEMAND

Under the circumstances, McCall hereby demands the following:

        1.      Immediately cease and desist from any use whatsoever of all McCall Marks,
including removal of the McCall Marks from the Site home page, metatags, each of the
pages therein, and each page to which the Site links, including the pages resolving at
SafeShopper.com[5];

        2.      Immediately cease and desist from reproducing or displaying the McCall
Designs on the Site or elsewhere, including removal of all images at the SafeShopper.com
site displaying the copyrighted McCall Designs[6];

        3.      Immediately cease and desist from selling, distributing, reproducing, copying,
displaying, marketing, advertising, promoting, disposing of, or otherwise exploiting any
pattern offered under any McCall Mark;

        4.      Provide written assurances that you have ceased offering discontinued
McCall patterns, and from using the McCall Marks and McCall Designs without McCall's
permission;

        5.      Provide a report detailing each and every use you made of any of the McCall
Marks;

        6.      Provide a report detailing each and every use you made of any of the McCall
Designs;

        7.      Provide a report accounting for each pattern manufactured, designed,
created, or distributed by McCalls, or any pattern substantially similar thereto, you have

locators: http://patterns.safeshopper.com/144/cat144.htm?757,
http://patterns.safeshopper.com/137/cat137.htm?757, and http://patterns.safeshopper.com/139/cat139.htm?757.

http://patterns.safeshopper.com/210/cat210.htm?366, and http://patterns.safeshopper.com/203/6968.htm?462.

ever sold or disposed of;

     8.      Provide a report of all patterns manufactured, designed, created, or
distributed by McCalls, or any patterns substantially similar thereto, you currently have in
your possession or direct or indirect control;

     9.      Provide a report detailing how you came to acquire the patterns you offered
for sale and sold at the Site under the McCall Marks or related brands;

     10.     Provide a detailed report of all advertising or promotion for which you are
directly or indirectly responsible, including for the Site, in which any McCall Mark or McCall
Design has appeared or was otherwise used, including in pay-for-performance search
engine placements.

McCall expects that you will comply with the first four (4) demands above by Friday,
February 7, 2003, and that you will comply with the remaining demands by Friday,
February 14, 2003.  In the event you do not meet those deadlines, McCall intends to file a
lawsuit against you.

This letter does not contain a complete statement by McCall as to the facts or law relating
to this matter, and nothing in or omitted from this letter is intended to be, nor should it be
construed as being, a waiver by McCall of any of its rights, claims, remedies, or causes of
action against you.  To the contrary, McCall expressly reserves all such rights, remedies,
positions of fact and law, and causes of action, whether at law or in equity, and shall
vigorously pursue the same.

Should you have any questions, do not hesitate to contact the undersigned directly by
telephone at [private].

Govern yourself accordingly.

Very Truly Yours,

NEWMAN & NEWMAN,
ATTORNEYS AT LAW, LLP



[Private]
